text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Mayors, council chairmen and councillors will have their salaries and allowances increased by at least 50 percent from the end of June.
- Dutch Ambassaor to Kenya Klaus Dahlgaard says foreign envoys should avoid supporting any political group in their country of accreditation.
- The government rules out any possibility of overhauling the 8-4-4 system of education.
- President Daniel arap Moi says the government will protect the lives of Kenyans.
- A rally in Mombasa calling for constitutional reforms and originally slated for Saturday has been postponed to June 21.
- A 14-year-old girl is raped for two days and nights by eight people in Kiambu district of central Kenya.
- President Moi says the ban on hawking in the city's central business district remains.
- Amnesty International advises Kenya's opposition to enter into consultations with the government on constitutional reforms instead of resorting to violence.

- The ruling KANU party's secretary-general accuses the opposition of applying the "jungle law" and further says they (opposition) are busy sponsoring illegal meetings aimed at destabilising the government.
